title: Father in College-Admissions Case Sentenced to Four Months in Prison
text:
BOSTON—A Los Angeles father who paid $400,000 to get his son into Georgetown University as a phony tennis recruit was sentenced to four months in prison, with the judge chastising him for buying a slot that shut out a deserving student.

In handing out her punishment Thursday to Stephen Semprevivo, the third parent to be sentenced in the national college-admissions scheme, U.S. District Judge Indira Talwani again portrayed the parents in the case as already greatly advantaged people who sought to gain an even greater edge....
description: A Los Angeles father who paid $400,000 to get his son into Georgetown University as a phony tennis recruit was sentenced to four months in prison, with the judge chastising him for buying a slot that shut out a deserving student.
